title: Before 1 January 2019, will the US federal government ban the manufacture, importation, possession, or sale of bump stocks?
preds: It’s official now. The rule is in the Federal Register: https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2018/12/26/2018-27763/bump-stock-type-devices

Acting AG Whitaker signed it on 12/18.  There have been reports that it would appear in the Federal Register today, but it has not as of noon EST.
https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2018/12/14#justice-department However, I believe it will appear in the next few days.  It doesn't become law until it appears.

DEPARTMENT OF JUSTICE 
Bump-Stock-Type Devices
(Billing Code: 4410-FY-P)
AGENCY: Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives; Department of Justice
ACTION: Final rule. 
https://www.justice.gov/opa/press-release/file/1120876/download Isn't this enough?
Seems like a done deal as of 12/18, provided I'm reading everything right.
I haven't found it in the Federal Register, so it's not official yet.  I've read that they intended to put it in tomorrow.
the rule was signed by AAG Whitaker Dec 18, 2018.
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-guns-bumpstocks/trump-bans-bump-stocks-used-in-las-vegas-mass-shooting-idUSKBN1OH1WW This is what happens when you take a couple of days off. . . .
Trump administration officially bans bump stocks https://www.cnn.com/2018/12/18/politics/bump-stocks-ban/index.html

Trump February 26th "I will write out bump stocks myself".
Nuther zero.

I too back off this too soon.
Too late to bump the bump stock forecast to 100% but what the heck.

O me of little faith! I backed off my forecast too soon. Trump administration officially bans bump stocks
https://edition.cnn.com/2018/12/18/politics/bump-stocks-ban/index.html

As @dsarin pointed out, CNN reported that the rule is out. DOJ officials announced this to CNN, before publication in the federal register which they say is supposed to happen this Friday. "...the final rule is published in the federal register -- likely this Friday -- according to senior DOJ officials." https://edition.cnn.com/2018/12/18/politics/bump-stocks-ban/index.html

Trump administration officially bans bump stocks
https://edition.cnn.com/2018/12/18/politics/bump-stocks-ban/index.html

Today's news that Trump is responding to Parkland shootings by increasing school discipline against black students (de facto the case) settles things for me.  He never gives in and neither do his supporters and government officials.
Adjusting for the passage of time and still radio silence.

Politico playbook: “House Dems eye quick action on guns in new Congress”: “House Democrats are planning to move several high-profile bills to combat gun violence soon after they take power in January, underscoring their belief that the political landscape has shifted dramatically on an issue that's plagued American society for decades. “With backing from House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) and key chairmen, Democrats will move to require federal background checks on all gun sales, part of a broader effort by the party to advance long-stalled gun control measures. While the proposal won't get through the Republican-run Senate, much less become law, getting through the House will be a win for the gun-control movement, which has little to cheer about since President Donald Trump was sworn into office.” 
~~~~~~~
COMMENT: I'm thinking that DJT will want to get out in front of the Democrats on gun issues by  issuing the bump stock ban ASAP
Reducing due to passage of time.
updating for passage of time. It's not going to happen.

I'm still finding this one especially tricky, but given there hasn't been any new news on this for 2-3 weeks and we're into the final two weeks of the year, it seems unlikely that it happens. I'm hesitant to go lower though, because it's still entirely possible that it's just going through the final administrative hurdles and will come out this week. I'm planning on lowering my estimate every day if I remember to do so.
No news when we were told that there would be. Think while there's more urgent concerns this may wait until after the new year.
Reducing previous forecast due to: - No new information on stages of this change, and quickly diminishing time.
Thanks to @nigster & @JMR2017 who alerted me to the high likelihood that the story on CBS Miami is probably recycled news from Nov 28th.  Darn!

Trump Administration To Announce Final Bump Stock Ban
CBS Miami
The Trump administration plans to announce the long-anticipated federal rule officially banning bump stocks in the coming days,  @Emil, @pietrokc, @JMR2017
They don't get much done this close to the winter holidays.
Down from 55%. Not published today either [1]. Only 11 more issues of the Federal Register to go. [1] https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2018/12/14

NRA lobbyists are in the back pocket of too many politicians. Greed is the only motivator within our current political arena. Common sense actions, doing the right thing for the right reason and the Will of the people do not enter into the thought process of today’s politicians.
Down from 60%. Not published today either [1]. [1] https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2018/12/13

https://www.reviewjournal.com/news/politics-and-government/trump-administrations-rule-to-ban-bump-stocks-languishes-1545760/ "Despite a report last month that the Trump administration would announce a ban on bump stocks “in the coming days,” a rule that would make it illegal to own the type of device used in the Oct. 1 shooting in Las Vegas continues to languish without any official explanation." "In the days since the CNN report, however, administration officials have rebuffed repeated requests by the Review-Journal for comment on the status of the rule." The whole piece is worth reading.
Little time left.  Bad political move.

Nov 28: CNN reports Trump to ban bump stocks without legislation in the "coming days" (https://www.cnn.com/2018/11/28/politics/final-bump-stock-ban/index.html)
Dec 4: KSTP reports they've received a memo detailing the new ban on bump stocks, but (strangely?) does not release the memo (https://kstp.com/news/kstp-obtains-federal-memo-detailing-ban-on-bump-stocks/5166175/)
Dec 13: No mention of bump stocks in the federal register since November 16th. (https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/search?conditions%5Bterm%5D=bump+stock&order=newest)
I'm following @pietrokc's logic and coming in line with him
Too close to their departure for Christmas.
Down from 65%. Not published today either [1]. [1] https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2018/12/12

Reducing my number given the delays, which I'm wondering are linked to the recent legal debate over Whitaker's nomination is holding up the finalization of the process.  I'm not especially clear about the final signatory process of final rules that have made it through the regulatory process, probably because the process is generally pro forma.  
President signs of (https://www.federalregister.gov/uploads/2011/01/the_rulemaking_process.pdf - pg 7 Q: What is the role of the President in developing a final rule?) However, this lawyer with a focus on gun rights / NRA (among other things) points out that the Attorney General signs off on final regulations and is not the only one to have questions whether the acting AG, Whitaker, appointed by Trump is a probably-legal-but-atypical manner, is legally able to perform the function of Attorney General (Democrat lawsuit in DC district, another in MD district court, and another in Supreme Court).
http://www.sdslaw.us/single-post/2018/12/09/Can-the-Acting-Attorney-General-enact-new-regulations
https://www.nytimes.com/2018/11/19/us/politics/democrats-lawsuit-whitaker-attorney-general.html
https://www.theusconstitution.org/news/sens-blumenthal-whitehouse-and-hirono-sue-trump-over-whitaker-appointment/
https://int.nyt.com/data/documenthelper/488-d-d-c-18-cv-02664-dckt-000001/7e324bc868a0d4b453b0/optimized/full.pdf#page=1
https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2018/11/13/matthew-whitaker-maryland-court-challenge/1986221002/ The Senate's research group clearly believes Whitaker's appointment is secure and their argument seems pretty well-founded, or at least secure enough to not general much risk.
https://fas.org/sgp/crs/misc/LSB10217.pdf
https://www.senate.gov/CRSpubs/3d313cc2-9515-4533-b1f0-3f762cd09007.pdf But none of this probably matters very much for the AG position since Trump has announced he's putting a former AG (from the G. H. W. Bush Admin) who probably will get enough bipartisan support to pass.  Grassley approves, and although he's stepping down as Chair of the Senate Judiciary, which must confirm the appointment, he is staying as a member.  And Graham is the probable replacement as the majority party senior member after Grassley, and Graham has publicly stated he'll do what he can to get Barr confirmed.  
https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/trump-confirms-he-will-pick-william-barr-as-his-next-attorney-general/2018/12/07/6e8d28ba-fa2d-11e8-863c-9e2f864d47e7_story.html?utm_term=.15f0b8b7d587
https://www.radioiowa.com/2018/12/11/senator-grassley-doesnt-expect-any-issues-in-confirming-new-attorney-general/
https://www.desmoinesregister.com/story/news/politics/2018/11/16/sen-chuck-grassley-gives-up-senate-judiciary-chair-head-finance-committee/2024820002/
https://www.businessinsider.com/lindsey-graham-likely-chair-senate-judiciary-committee-2018-11
https://thehill.com/homenews/administration/420268-graham-vows-to-push-trumps-ag-pic-through-judiciary-committee
https://www.breitbart.com/politics/2018/12/07/lindsey-graham-do-everything-power-confirm-william-barr-attorney-general/ Which might matter if the DOJ is waiting to finalize the rule until they have an undisputed Attorney General to sign off on any pending issues, especially as a way to reduce later challenges (which in the case of this rule seem pretty likely already).  I don't know if they are obligated to publish a final rule within a certain time limit after it completes the final OMB review.  Because of the Congressional Review Act, both houses of Congress must receive and approve rules before they are finalized by committees dealing with issues relevant to the rule, and although both houses have to issue a joint resolution to overturn the rule, and this doesn't seem to me to be a rule likely to get significant push back from enough people to be an issue, I can see that the issue of the AG's authority might hold it up. But regardless of whether the authority issue at the DOJ has anything to do with a delay, the final rule hasn't made it's way to the GAO for Congressional review.  And once any major rule (i.e. economically significant) is submitted to congress, the GAO will track it.  Although a rule can be published first, this one doesn't seem to have been so far, and the GAO tracking page also doesn't seem to show that the DOJ's bump-stock type device rule has been submitted to Congress either.  
https://www.gao.gov/legal/other-legal-work/congressional-review-act/
https://www.gao.gov/products/D07440#mt=e-report
https://www.gao.gov/decisions/majrule/fedrule2.pdf I'm also not sure what to make of the ATF's memo on gun accessories yesterday which @Daveinsea posted earlier
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/796168 Tagging others active here who might have better understanding of the regulatory process: @Emil, @pietrokc, @Anneinak, @cmeinel, @nigster, @Wildwood2000, @JMR2017

Al....most.....there..... The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives sent this bulletin at 12/10/2018 04:13 PM EST Effective Immediately: Discontinuance of Accessory Classifications  The Firearms Technology Industry Services Branch (FTISB) classifies firearms as defined by the Gun Control Act (GCA) and National Firearms Act (NFA) based on the configuration and the design features of the firearm as submitted by members of the industry. Effective immediately, any requests for a determination on how an accessory affects the classification of a firearm under the GCA or NFA must include a firearm with the accessory already installed. Except in cases of conditional import determinations, FTISB will not issue a determination on an accessory unless it is attached to the submitted firearm. If you have previously submitted a sample accessory for classification, FTISB will be returning your sample without classification. FTISB will contact you in the near future with further instructions to facilitate the return of your sample. In past cases involving the ATF and firearms submitted that have been determined to be NFA items the ATF has returned them when the person/company involved possesses the correct SOT. In instances where the correct SOT has not been in place those items have not been returned. https://content.govdelivery.com/accounts/usatf/bulletins/22189c1

Reducing my forecast simply to put less at risk by being closer to consensus. The 'announcement in days or weeks' shortly after the tragic Las Vagas anniversary has not materialized; the regulatory/legislative ban would be divisive to the President's base at a time of heightened turmoil; the move would not improve Republican fund-raising capability. There may be a moral argument and informed debate, but I am unaware of it.

Reducing from 95% due to time running out. Was 95% around 3 Dec so should go down by ~25% every week.
Follow the trendline. Great initial enthusiasm, the the inevitable realization of typical congressional inaction
Downgrading from 100% based on the passage of time. We were supposed to hear something within a couple of days and we've heard nothing.
Congress is owned by the NRA. I see no short term changes in any gun laws.
I doubt that this can become law before January 1.
The NRA has the Senate and House in its pocket.   When that changes, maybe we will see some gun control.

Well I have no idea what this is (and I didn't see a link to the Justice Dept memo they are referring to).  I also can't tell if the Justice Department would circulate a memo like this to prompt reaction from gun sellers and law enforcement agencies (since the article says an ATF spokepeson claims they're still considering comments from the public period this last summer) or if they've delayed posting the final rule to give sellers and law enforcement time to prepare for mad chaos when the rule is proposed and people get angry.  If the thread is anything to go by and there is still only a 5% expectation that this will go through by the end of the year, maybe this one will end up being a bit of a shock.  On the other hand, it makes sense, given the economic significance and the fact that both gun sellers and law enforcement will need to prepare for next steps.  So the final publishing seems to me to be pretty firmly set, still actively in the process on many levels, but not clear when it will be finalized in the Federal Register.  Still, it seems to me moving ahead and therefore more likely to be published within 1-2 weeks than that it will be delayed having already reached everything but final sign off.  And the memo does suggest a typical 90 day period after the rule is published for it to go into effect, though it seems from the question details that this will not affect the outcome of the question since the publishing counts as a formal federal ban. https://kstp.com/national/feds-mum-on-bump-stock-ban-memo-obtained-by-kstp/5167573/
https://kstp.com/news/kstp-obtains-federal-memo-detailing-ban-on-bump-stocks/5166175/?cat=1
This is anticipated to happen soon, and has been 'promised' in days or weeks; may be a goodwill gift for the festive season, bizarre as it sounds. Time's running out ...
if they had any sense they would act quickly
Until the NRA has no lobbying power in DC, there will be no movement with ANY gun laws.

No reason to be more optimistic than that.  ATF brass go to industry jobs and will operate out of self interest, not public interest.
Republicans busy taking care of what they can in lame duck session, and will block this.

According to CNN(1), a decision is imminent. However, it should be noted that this move from the administration is labeled a "federal rule," and is not congressional legislation.  "Under the new rule, bump stock owners would be required to destroy or surrender the devices to authorities. Members of the public will be given 90 days to turn in or otherwise discard their bump stocks, according to a source familiar with the final rule." (CNN) Notably, its effectiveness is most certainly unknowable. Enforcement will likely be split along state party lines. As one source(2) notes: "The rule may also face opposition through court challenges as seen against similar state- and city-level initiatives, with lawsuits filed in Florida and Ohio." (1) https://www.cnn.com/2018/11/28/politics/final-bump-stock-ban/index.html
(2) https://www.washingtonexaminer.com/news/trump-administration-to-unveil-final-bump-stock-ban-soon

One detail is holding it up - Under the new rule, bump stock owners would be required to destroy or surrender the devices to authorities. Members of the public will be given 90 days to turn in or otherwise discard their bump stocks, according to a source familiar with the final rule. Concern has been around the penalty and burden of proof for current owners. It will need a re-write if they wish to have a functioning regulation that doesn't get instant lawsuit treatment.
Would be a relatively painless regulation for the gun rights people to accept, and it sounds like the rule-making process is well advanced.
Are you kidding? Politicians supported by the NRA restricting anything to do with firearms?
NRA opposes, Paul Ryan is irrelevant.
It's not the right timing for the NRA, Christmas and a boost in sales are around the corner
